scientific_summary: Disgust decreases through sensory regulation, cognitive reappraisal, and exposure when appropriate (Rozin & Fallon, 1987).

immediate.title: Sensory reset
instructions: Inhale a pleasant scent (citrus, mint) or sip cool water to cleanse the palate.
Rinse hands or face with warm water, noticing the change in sensation.
Exhale slowly and repeat a grounding phrase: 'This feeling will pass.'

evidence.source: Olatunji & McKay, Journal of Anxiety Disorders, 2007
evidence.summary: Positive sensory input reduces disgust intensity by replacing aversive cues.

immediate.title: Posture release
instructions: Stand tall and roll shoulders back three times.
Open arms wide, inhale deeply, then exhale with a sigh while bringing hands to heart.
Repeat twice, focusing on expanding chest space to counter the urge to recoil.

evidence.summary: Embodied cleansing actions (open posture, washing) reduce lingering disgust reactions.

immediate.title: Urge surfing wave
instructions: Notice the urge to recoil and rate it 0-10.
Breathe in for 4, out for 6 while imagining the urge rising and falling like a wave.
Track the rating every 30 seconds until it drops by at least 2 points.

evidence.source: Bowen et al., Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention, 2014
evidence.summary: Urge surfing decreases avoidance impulses and improves disgust tolerance.

short_term.title: Context reappraisal
instructions: Describe the triggering stimulus in factual terms, removing adjectives.
List two alternative explanations (e.g., cultural difference, protective instinct).
State one constructive next step (set boundary, seek information, clean up).

evidence.summary: Cognitive reappraisal effectively modifies disgust reactions by reframing meaning.

short_term.title: Values check
instructions: Identify which personal value felt violated (e.g., cleanliness, respect).
Write one sentence on how you can honor that value healthily (clean, communicate, exit).
Commit to the aligned action within 24 hours.

evidence.summary: Disgust often signals moral violation; addressing the value reduces emotional residue.

short_term.title: Protective action plan
instructions: List three practical steps to restore cleanliness or safety (sanitize, ventilate, reorganize).
Assign each step a time estimate and required tools.
Begin the quickest step immediately to regain agency.

evidence.source: Curtis et al., Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B, 2011
evidence.summary: Goal-directed cleansing behaviors reduce disgust intensity and perceived contamination.

long_term.title: Gradual exposure hierarchy
instructions: Rank related stimuli from least to most disgusting.
Begin exposure with the least intense cue (e.g., images) while practicing slow breathing.
Progress up the hierarchy as tolerance increases, noting mastery after each step.

evidence.source: Rozin & Fallon, Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 1987
evidence.summary: Exposure therapy desensitizes disgust reactions by repeated non-harmful contact.

long_term.title: Compassion cultivation
instructions: Visualize someone who elicited disgust and imagine them as a vulnerable child.
Offer phrases of compassion ('May you be free from suffering').
Shift attention to your own reaction, offering the same compassion to yourself.

evidence.source: Hofmann et al., Clinical Psychology Review, 2011
evidence.summary: Compassion meditation reduces disgust and increases prosocial responding.

long_term.title: Cultural literacy practice
instructions: Pick a cultural practice or cuisine that previously triggered disgust.
Research its history and meaning, noting at least three positive intentions behind it.
Share one learning with a friend or journal about how understanding shifted your reaction.

evidence.source: Koleva et al., Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2012
evidence.summary: Perspective-taking and cultural knowledge reduce moralized disgust responses.

friend_support.title: Normalize the reaction, not the trigger
instructions: Acknowledge your friend's feeling without judgment ("Anyone could feel thrown by that smell").
Invite them to identify the value underneath the reaction (health, respect).
Offer to help with one concrete clean-up or boundary-setting action.

evidence.summary: Validation paired with value clarification reduces interpersonal disgust contagion.

friend_support.title: Exposure partner check-in
instructions: Help your friend rank triggers and choose an easy first exposure to do together (photos, descriptions).
Guide them through slow breathing during the exposure and rate discomfort every minute.
Celebrate progress and log ideas for the next step.

evidence.summary: Supported exposure reduces disgust sensitivity more effectively than solo practice.

self_repair.title: Repair after expressing disgust
instructions: Name the behavior without shaming the person ("I wrinkled my nose when you served that dish").
Explain the automatic reaction and affirm the relationship value (curiosity, respect).
Offer to learn more or try a small portion to show willingness to reconnect.

evidence.source: Chapman & Anderson, Review of General Psychology, 2014
evidence.summary: Repairing disgust expressions with empathy maintains closeness and reduces offense.

self_repair.title: Set a respectful boundary
instructions: Clarify what specific cue you need to limit (texture, environment).
Propose an alternative that honors both needs (different utensil, ventilation, location).
Confirm follow-up to revisit how the arrangement is working.

evidence.summary: Boundaries that respect pathogen concerns while protecting social bonds reduce recurring disgust conflicts.
